docs.title: Making data findable
docs.text: This site provides recommendations for making research data publications findable in common metadata flows so they can be discovered, linked, cited, and followed up over time.

docs.title: What do we mean by “findable”?
docs.text:
In this context, findability means: that a data publication can be uniquely identified and reliably connected to:

  • the people involved (e.g. ORCID)
  • the organisations involved (e.g. ROR)
  • related outputs such as publications (e.g. DOI)
  • and other relevant contexts (e.g. projects, grants, versions)

In practice, this depends on persistent identifiers and structured, machine-readable metadata that travel between repositories, indexing services, and organisational systems.

docs.title: Who is this for?
docs.text:
These recommendations are intended for:

  • Researchers who publish, describe, and cite research data.
  • Research organisations that provide policies, infrastructure, and support services for data publication.

docs.title: Recommendations for organisations
docs.text:
• Strategic implementation
  • Infrastructure and standards
  • Support and services

docs.title: Ensure structured and automated capture of core metadata for data publications
docs.text:
Research organisations should ensure that core metadata for data publications are recorded in structured fields within local systems and, wherever possible, populated automatically from authoritative registers and persistent identifiers.

As a minimum, this should include:

  • the persistent identifier of the data publication (e.g. DOI)
  • the researcher’s ORCID
  • organisational identifiers (e.g. ROR)
  • a link to related publications (e.g. DOI)

docs.title: Why?
docs.text: When metadata are entered manually or as free text only, the risk of inconsistency and error increases. Using structured fields combined with automated population from controlled registries reduces the administrative burden on researchers and improves opportunities for automated monitoring, interoperability, and traceability across systems.

docs.title: Manage and assure the quality of identifiers and basic metadata describing the organisation
docs.text: Identifiers (PIDs) and accompanying metadata describing the research organisation should be managed and quality-assured in relevant external infrastructures and services. These include organisational identifiers (e.g. ROR), enclosing official institutional names and other metadata used for expressing institutional affiliation. The use of organisational identifiers should be enabled in local infrastructures and systems, and they should be a preferred method of sharing metadata with external services.

docs.title: Why?
docs.text: Missing or inconsistent organisational metadata in external services impairs the ability to track data publications, link them to the correct institution and reuse information in national and international metadata flows. If organisational PIDs are used and the organisation's core metadata is properly managed, it will reduce the need for manual input by researchers, as well as improve traceability and data quality throughout the research information chain.

docs.title: Work with automation and interoperable connections between systems
docs.text: Automated and interoperable information flows between relevant research information systems should be pursued, for example between data repositories, CRIS systems, data management planning tools and other administrative systems. Preventing manual duplication of work for researchers as well as research support staff should be a set goal.

docs.title: Why?
docs.text: Lack of integration and interoperability between systems leads to repeated manual entries, varying metadata quality and difficulties in tracking data publications. Automated and standardised workflows improve traceability, quality and efficiency and reduce the administrative burden for both researchers and supporting functions.

docs.title: Make data publications visible and recognised in academic assessment
docs.text: Research organisations should ensure that data publications can be made visible and taken into account in local processes for academic assessment, monitoring, and research evaluation—particularly where the data publications are of high quality and comply with the FAIR principles.

docs.title: Why?
docs.text: When data publications are not recognised as research contributions, work on them tends to be given low priority. The lack of clear incentives is a known barrier to both data publication and good research data management. Enabling data publications to be considered in evaluation contexts creates better conditions for long-term change.

docs.title: Establish organisational presence in external data repositories
docs.text: Research data support functions should, where possible, establish and manage organisational presence in external data repositories used by the institution's researchers. This will enable monitoring and quality assertion of data publications.

docs.title: Why?
docs.text: When data publications are created in external repositories without organisational support, there is a lack of effective ways to find them and quality assure them, which impairs traceability, local follow-up and national output reporting practices.

docs.title: How to keep your organization's ROR record updated
docs.text:
To ensure maximum visibility and traceability for the organization's output and impact, it is important to make sure that the information connected to ROR is correct and updated, in particular that all common (alternative) names and acronyms are included and searchable.

  1. Search for the organization at ror org to view existing details.
  2. If something is missing or incorrect, click Suggest a change and follow the instructions. If adding a new organization, please review Criteria for inclusion first.
  3. Enter as much information as needed and submit the form.
  4. Requests are manually reviewed and changes typically appear in 4-6 weeks.

docs.title: Recommendations for researchers
docs.text:
• Publication and citation
  • Metadata and identifiers
  • Tools and workflows

docs.title: Use persistent identifiers (PIDs) when publishing and describing data
docs.text: All data publications should be assigned a persistent identifier (e.g. DOI). Any research outputs that use or refer to the data should use its unique PID. Identifiers used to describe and link the data to researchers (ORCID) and organisations (ROR) should be specified in the accompanying metadata.

docs.title: Why?
docs.text: PIDs make up a fundamental infrastructure enabling data publications and other research outputs to be found, cited, followed up and linked to the right researcher and organisation over time.

docs.title: Add links to related publications and projects when publishing data
docs.text: Researchers should record links to relevant publications and projects in the metadata of a data publication at the point of publication, using the structured fields provided by the repository.

docs.title: Why?
docs.text: When links between data, publications, and projects are captured directly in the metadata, they become machine-readable and can be reused for monitoring, reporting, and analysis without the need for manual enrichment.

docs.title: How?
docs.text:
• Use the repository’s designated fields for related identifiers, such as Related identifier or Related publication.
  • Provide the links in the form of persistent identifiers where available (e.g. a DOI or project identifier).
  • Add these links at the time of publication to ensure they are included in downstream metadata flows.

docs.title: Publish research data as independent, citable objects
docs.text: Research data underlying scientific results should be published as independent data publications in an appropriate data repository, rather than attaching them as supplemental materials or referring to them informally.

docs.title: Why?
docs.text: When data are not packaged as independent data publications (datasets) with accompanying metadata, they become invisible in many information flows, impairing traceability, reuse and recognition of the data as a valuable research output.

docs.title: Cite data publications using formal references according to established data citation principles
docs.text: Data publications underlying scientific results should be cited using formal references in a publication's bibliography, in accordance with established data citation principles.

docs.title: Why?
docs.text: When data publications are not cited as formal references, they are often excluded from metadata flows and automated indexing, which impairs traceability, citability and the ability to follow up research data as valuable research outputs.

docs.title: Make data publications visible in research communication and academic portfolios
docs.text: Researchers should actively highlight their data publications in research communication and academic portfolios—such as CVs, personal websites, research profiles, and applications—in ways that make the data publications clearly identifiable and citable.

docs.title: Why?
docs.text: Data publications are increasingly recognised as standalone research contributions, yet they risk being overlooked if they remain confined to repository interfaces. When data publications are not visible in academic portfolios and research communication, they are difficult to take into account in assessment, monitoring, and research evaluation. This, in turn, reduces incentives to invest time in data publication and good research data management.

docs.title: How?
docs.text:
• Include data publications as a separate category in your CV, for example under the heading Data publications or Research data.
  • Use the persistent identifier of the data publication (e.g. a DOI) as a link, so that the data publication can be accessed and cited directly.
  • Make data publications visible on personal websites and research profiles (e.g. ORCID or local profile pages), in the same way as publications.
  • Where data publications are central to a research output, refer to them explicitly in research descriptions and applications.

docs.title: How to describe and share your data through a repository service
docs.text:
Select a suitable repository for your data. Some commonly used alternatives are:

Zenodo - Generalist repository (many different types of data are accepted) hosted by CERN. Instructions are available at Zenodo.org

SND-DORIS - Generalist repository hosted by CERN. Instructions are available at SND.se

re3data - Comprehensive registry of existing research data repositories. Here you can search for suitable data repositories and find domain specific repositories (focused on specific data types).

docs.title: How to add works (e.g. datasets) with a DataCite DOI to your ORCID record
docs.text:
1. Login to your ORCID account
  2. Scroll down to Works
  3. Click on ADD +
  4. Select Search and Link
  5. Click on DataCite and authorize access to login to DataCite Commons
  6. Under Manage settings, enable ORCID Auto-update and authorize access again

From your ORCID account you can add additional Link wizards to automatically populate your ORCID record (e.g. CrossRef and OpenAire). Video guides are available at the ORCID webpage.
